page.title: 20Local Dialects
page.content: The "Black Country" has always had a distinctive dialect. It is claimed that it derives from Early English, (many words are found in Chaucer). Over the years the growth of mining and the iron industry has attracted workers from beyond the region adding other variations, particularly Shropshire. Radio and TV is supposed a major cause in the demise of dialect, and it is spoken most fully now to entertain, or for preservation. Some elements survive in normal speech "I ay" for "I am not", "Yo cor" for "You cannot". "Yo am" replaces "You are". Words still in popular use are "share" for "shall not", while "Me" is used for "My". Compressions are "cum" for "comb" "reglar" for "regular". "H" is usually an unsounded consonant while "a" is pronounced shortly as in cat, e.g.path, bath, unlike nearby Birmingham's "ar".
